job_title: Donor Specialist in San Bernardino, CA
pros:
I was very excited about this job when I started. 
It feels great to be working for a not-for-profit organization.
Benefits package is great. 
Training is in depth and hands on.
Staffing is different every day, so you never get tired of seeing the same people.
cons:

Management barely acknowledges you unless you are making mistakes or have complaints against you.
Zero room for growth within the company.
Lots of "big personalities"

job_title: Donor Specialist in San Bernardino, CA
pros: New locations and donors everyday, no chance of boredom. Mobile teams can make draws fun, always music to work with. Lots of interesting sites you wouldn't be able to see as an average phlebotomist.
cons:
Sporadic hours (example: mom-0345-1600. Tuesday 0715-1350, Wednesday 0400-1800) no set days off, frequent and last minute schedule changes and it's difficult to get scheduling to approve switches or covers. Mandatory overtime, shifts frequently go 30 minutes to hours over scheduled clock out time (parents using daycare, beware) managers, HR and scheduling have a loose understanding of labor law (make sure you know your rights) it's difficult to discuss anything of importance with managers (different locations, different hours) if you do track down a manger they blow over you thoughts and concerns to scold or add to work load. 
  Cross training is required without worthy compensation. 
   Faulty equipment is put back in the field even after being taken out of service, without getting fixed.
    Company vehicles have cameras that are only supposed to record 15 seconds before and after an accident or incident but in reality they record and play back whole car rides to "counsel" you.
 30 min lunch is taken before site arrival, so you're having your lunch between 0430-0700, 90% of shifts. Second lunches are never given even if you didn't get your full 30 or if you work over 12 hours.
  Understaffed
Projections are always off, which leads to understaffing and being scolded for longer wait times, which is completely out of DONOR SPECIALISTs hands.
